prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning.  Here is the text: One objection to the views of those who, like Mr. Gulick, believe isolation itself to be a cause of modification of species deserves attention, namely, the entire absence of change where, if this were a _vera causa_, we should expect to find it. In Ireland we have an excellent test case, for we know that it has been separated from Britain since the end of the glacial epoch, certainly many thousand years. Yet hardly one of its mammals, reptiles, or land molluscs has undergone the slightest change, even although there is certainly a distinct difference in the environment both inorganic and organic. That changes have not occurred through natural selection, is perhaps due to the less severe struggle for existence owing to the smaller number of competing species; but, if isolation itself were an efficient cause, acting continuously and c.u.mulatively, it is incredible that a decided change should not have been produced in thousands of years. That no such change has occurred in this, and many other cases of isolation, seems to prove that it is not in itself a cause of modification.
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning.  Here is the text:
format_prompt: Use the following format for your answers: ##TEXT## your_new_text ##TEXTEND##
stories: ##TEXT## The argument against the perspective held by individuals such as Mr. Gulick, who view isolation as a direct cause of species modification, merits consideration. The argument lies in the conspicuous lack of change in environments where, if isolation were indeed a contributing factor, we would anticipate witnessing such alterations. An exemplary instance of this can be observed in Ireland, which has been disconnected from Britain since the conclusion of the glacial era, a considerable time span. Despite this, there is an almost negligible difference in the mammals, reptiles, and land mollusks when compared to their British counterparts, even though the environmental conditions, both organic and inorganic, distinctly vary. The absence of changes cannot be attributed to natural selection faced by a lesser struggle for existence due to fewer competing species. If isolation were indeed a potent and cumulative cause, one would expect marked changes over thousands of years. However, the fact that such changes have not manifested, not only in this instance but in numerous other isolation cases, suggests that isolation is not, in itself, a cause for modification. ##TEXTEND##

##TEXT## The argument challenging the view of people like Mr. Gulick, who believe isolation leads to species modification, is worth considering. The basis of this argument is the noticeable absence of changes in environments where, if isolation played a role, we would expect to see modifications. A prime example is Ireland, which has been separated from Britain since the end of the glacial era. Despite this isolation, the mammals, reptiles, and land mollusks in Ireland are remarkably similar to those in Britain, even though the environmental conditions differ significantly. This lack of change cannot be attributed to natural selection from less competition due to fewer species. If isolation were a significant and cumulative cause, we would expect noticeable changes over thousands of years. However, the lack of such changes, not only in this case but in many other isolation instances, suggests that isolation is not a direct cause of modification. ##TEXTEND##

##TEXT## The argument questioning the perspective of individuals like Mr. Gulick, who assert that isolation results in species transformation, is worth contemplating. The heart of this argument lies in the conspicuous absence of alterations in settings where, if isolation were a factor, we would anticipate observing transformations. An illustrative example is Ireland, which has been detached from Britain since the conclusion of the glacial era. Despite this isolation, the mammals, reptiles, and terrestrial mollusks in Ireland are strikingly comparable to those in Britain, even though the ecological conditions vary significantly. This stagnation cannot be ascribed to natural selection from reduced competition due to fewer species. If isolation were a substantial and accumulative influence, we would expect perceptible changes over millennia. However, the absence of such changes, not only in this instance but in numerous other isolation cases, hints that isolation is not a direct agent of transformation. ##TEXTEND##

This lack of diversity cannot be attributed to natural selection resulting from reduced competition. If separation was a substantial and enduring factor, considerable variations would likely emerge over thousands of years. However, the absence of these changes, not only in this case but in many other isolated examples, implies that separation might not be the primary evolutionary driver. ##TEXTEND##
